Three interesting papers published during this review period demonstrated the ability of XRF techniques to give chemical information on multilayered structures. Doomes and McGuire 391 reported their work on ion beam sputtered multilayer SiO 2 / Ta 2 O 5 coatings on fused SiO 2 substrates. XAS gave chemical and structural features of the dielectric multilayered NO 2 /Ta 2 O 5 mirror coatings. Rajput et al.
392 studied the depth resolved structural information of heavy ion induced phase formation in Si/Fe/Si trilayers. XRF measurements gave the Fe depth distribution, whilst Mossbauer spectroscopy and XAFS provided information about changes in local structure. Synthesis and characterisation of a new four-layer Aurivillius phase Bi 2 SrNa 2 Nb 4 O 15 was reported by Liang et al.
393 Following a solid state reaction of Bi 2 SrNa 2 Nb 4 O 9 and NaNbO 3 at 1100  C, XRD was used to show the resultant crystalline structure and XRF and thermogravimetry used for the measurement of composition the multilayers formed.

Li 2 MnO 3 nanowires were fabricated via a molten-salt method.
Firstly, 10 g NaNO 3 and 0.2 g MnF 2 , acquired from the facile reaction of MnCO 3 and HF, were ground for approximately 10 min to obtain a homogeneous mixture, and then heattreated for 3 h at 540 1C. The mixture was subsequently washed with a large amount of deionized water and absolute ethanol to remove residual impurities, and then dried in the oven at 70 1C to obtain the Mn 2 O 3 nanowires. Secondly, 5 g LiNO 3 was mixed with 0.1 g Mn 2 O 3 nanowires to fabricate Li 2 MnO 3 by the above procedure under the same conditions. For comparison, Li 2 MnO 3 was also synthesized by a solid-state reaction starting from MnCO 3 and Li 2 CO 3 in a mole ratio of 1 : 1 and then calcined under an air atmosphere at 800 1C for 5 h.

A number of other potential battery cathode materials have been synthesised using hydrothermal means, for example, ferrates and manganates. The case of LiMnO 2 is particularly interesting. The material was first reported in 1996 by the group of Bruce and the material shown to have highly desirable electrochemical characteristics.
22 The synthetic route first used involved two steps: the ceramic synthesis of NaMnO 2 from Na 2 CO 3 and Mn 2 O 3 , followed by ion-exchange with a solution of lithium bromide in alcohol. The stannate ZnSnO 3 , containing Sn(IV) as the B-site cation, has been reported to form as a cubic perovskite from reaction between zinc acetate and SnCl 4 in NaOH solution at 200 1C.
201 In terms of synthesis, this is an interesting result since the material may also exist as the ilmenite polymorph, and also decomposes above 750 1CtoZn 2 SnO 4 and SnO 2 , thus precluding the use of conventional solid-state synthesis.
ZnSnO 3 has gas sensing properties that are enhanced by the ﬁne powders produced by hydrothermal reaction.
201 The same synthesis method for ZnSnO 3 has recently been modiﬁed by use of solution additives that have clear templating eﬀects: reaction at only 85 1C in the presence of surfactant gives highly facetted microcrystals whose gas sensing properties showed selectivity dependent on which crystal faces were presented.
202 In contrast, the addition of D-fructose at 180 1C results in the formation of ﬁne, needle-shaped crystals of a few nanometres in diameter and these were found to have favourable photocatalysis properties.
203 The polymorphism in ZnSnO 3 warrants further investigation since the hydrothermal products have so far only been analysed using laboratory powder X-ray diﬀraction and not subjected to comprehensive structural investigation.

3.1.1 Tantalates. NaTaO 3 has long been recognized as an eﬃcient UV-light photocatalyst for overall water splitting.
46–57 It has a band gap of 4.0 eV and can be synthesized by solidstate, 46–48,53,56 hydrothermal, 49,52,54,55 sol–gel 50,51 and molten salt methods.
57 As a first example, Kato and Kudo reported highly efficient splitting of pure water into H 2 and O 2 over the NaTaO 3 photocatalyst. The quantum yield of the NaTaO 3 (0.05 wt% NiO as a co-catalyst) photocatalyst prepared by the solid-state reaction method was 28% for water splitting at 270 nm.
46–48 In order to increase the surface area of NaTaO 3 bulk particles, many researchers attempted to use other synthetic routes to prepare nano-sized particles as an extension of the study on the NaTaO 3 photocatalyst. Kondo et al. synthesized a colloidal array of NaTaO 3 nanoparticles using threedimensional mesoporous carbon as a template, which was replicated by the colloidal array of silica nanospheres. After burning out the mesoporous carbon matrix, a colloidal array of NaTaO 3 nanoparticles with a size of 20 nm and a surface area of 34 m 2 g 1 was obtained. Compared to non-nanostructured bulk NaTaO 3 particles, the nanostructured NaTaO 3 exhibited more than 3 times higher photocatalytic activity for overall water splitting.
54 Shortly afterwards, Shi and Li et al. developedafastandfacilemethodfor the preparation of NaTaO 3 nanocrystals via a microwave-assisted hydrothermal process.
55 An indirect transformation route from Ta 2 O 5 to Na 2 Ta 2 O 6 and to NaTaO 3 was proposed as the main reason for that pure NaTaO 3 could be synthesized in a rather short time (less than 3 h) under mild condition s. The water splitting efficiency of NaTaO 3 nanocrystals prepared by this approach was more than two times higher than that prepared from conventional hydrothermal synthesis. Recently, the nano-sized NaTaO 3 ,prepared by an exo-template method with a crystallite size of about 25 nm, showed an 18 times higher hydrogen evolution rate than NaTaO 3 synthesized by a solid-state reaction method (Fig. 2).
56 The hydrogen production activity of NaTaO 3 obtained from the exo-template synthesis could be further improved by about 30–40 times by mixing with reduced graphene oxide and using Au as a co-catalyst. However, it did not show the improvement of activity for NaTaO 3 prepared from solid-state reaction under identical conditions.

Zinc molybdate phosphors doped with Tm 3+ and Yb 3+ ions, ZnMoO 4 :Tm 3+ ,Yb 3+ , were prepared by a hydrothermal (HT) process. In a typical hydrothermal reaction, a 10 mM mixture of Zn/Yb/Tm (Zn(NO 3 ) 2 4H 2 O/Yb(NO 3 ) 3 5H 2 O/Tm(NO 3 )5H 2 O) in distilled water was prepared in a beaker by constant stirring with a magnetic stirrer. In the above solution, 10 mM cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) was added and stirred for about 1 hour to obtain a transparent solution. The amount of CTAB was fixed to adjust the ratio of metal ions to CTAB uniformly such that all the metal ions get properly capped by CTAB. In a separate beaker, 10 mM (NH 4 ) 6 Mo 7 O 24 4H 2 O was prepared in distilled water and added to the above solution drop by drop. The pH of the resulting solution was adjusted to about 9 using aqueous ammonia solution. Then, 30 mL of the colloidal suspension obtained above was poured into a 50 mL Teflon lined stainless steel autoclave and kept at 180 1C for various time periods. In the case of alkali metal ion substituted samples, an appropriate amount of MNO 3 (M = Li, Na, K, Rb) was added into the Zn solution before mixing with the Mo-solution.
The solid obtained was centrifuged, washed multiple times with distilled water followed by ethanol and freeze dried for 12 hours.
The powder sample was further calcined at various temperatures from 500 1Cto8001C for 3 h to get the final highly crystalline oxide phosphor. For comparison, ZnMoO 4 :Tm 3+ ,Yb 3+ samples were also prepared by a solid-state reaction method. In the solid-state reaction, analytical grade ZnCO 3 , MoO 3 ,Yb 2 O 3 ,Tm 2 O 3 and M 2 CO 3 (M = Li, Na, K, Rb) were mixed thoroughly with the help of ethanol using a mortar and pestle, dried in air and calcined at 650 1C for 3 h.

Figure 1 schematically illustrates the methods and preparation steps adopted for the synthesis of LiVMoO 6 . As is seen from the ﬁgure, ﬁve manners were used to produce the phase. Solid-state reaction (method A) and soft-combustion synthesis (method B) were applied following the procedure described in [1– 4]. LiVMoO 6 was obtained also by melt quenching at different rates (method C—cooling rate 10 3 K/s and D—cooling rate 10 4 –10 5 K/s), and crystallization of a glass (method E). Glasses were prepared using reagent grade Li 2 CO 3 ,V 2 O 5 and MoO 3 as starting compounds.
The homogenized batches were melted for 10 min. in air in alumina crucibles at 600–800 C depending on the melting temperatures of the compositions. Owing to the high crystallization tendency of the melts, high cooling rates (10 4 –10 5 K/s) were applied using the roller-quenching method in order to deﬁne the glass formation region. Only fragmented 1–3 cm ﬂat pieces, about 50–100 lm thick, were produced. By visual observation it was assumed that those compositions, in which vitreous pieces are above 2/3 of the samples, were identiﬁed as glasses.

Freshly prepared CuO sample was divided into ﬁve equal parts. One of the parts was kept as a reference CuO (0 % Zn), labelled as S1, while other parts were used to prepare Zn doped CuO samples using 2, 4, 6 and 8 % concentration of Zn and labelled as S2, S3, S4 and S5, respectively.
Doping was performed by mechanical mixing of Zn and CuO, according to speciﬁc stoichiometric calculations, using pistol and mortar and then samples were heated at 400 °C for 24 h in the presence of air for solid state reaction. X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements for determination of structural parameters of the samples were carried out with X’Pert PRO 3040/60 using Cu k a radiation (wavelength = 1.5418 A ˚ ). Surface morphology was studied using the scanning electron microscope, JEOL JSM-6480LV. Thermo scientiﬁc NICOLET 6700, FTIR spectrometer was used to study absorption and related vibrational modes and optical properties were studied by diffused reﬂectance spectroscopy using Lambda-950Perkin Elmer spectrometer. Sample pellets each of thickness 4.01 mm were prepared for UV–Vis.
analysis. The reﬂectance and absorbance data were used to ﬁnd different optical parameters.

LiMn 2 O 4 nanowires were fabricated via a solid state reaction of b-MnO 2 nanowires and lithium hydroxide. The synthesis of b -MnO 2 nanowires can be seen in our previous report 36 . Typically, manganese sulfate (0.338 g) and potassium chlorate (0.246 g) were dissolved in 25 mL of distilled water under vigorous stirring to form a homogeneous solution. The mixture was then transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave and kept in an oven at 200uCfor 12 h. After being treated, the obtained b-MnO 2 nanowires were collected and then mixed with lithium hydroxide with mole ratio of 150.55. After annealing at 750uC for 10 h in air, the LiMn 2 O 4 nanowires were obtained.

All chemicals were of analytical and were directly used without any treatment. In a typical procedure, stochiometric amounts of Bi(NO 3 ) 3 5H 2 O and Ti(OC 3 H 7 ) 4 , a certain Bi/Ti ratio, was dissolved in 10 mL of deionized water with dilute nitric acid under vigorous stirring at room temperature. The pH value of the ﬁnal solution was adjusted using potassium hydroxide. Before being transferred to a Teﬂon-lined stainless autoclave (23 mL capacity), the solution mixture was prepared under an ultrasonic water bath for 30 min and kept at a ﬁlling ratio of 80% (v/v). The hydrothermal synthesis was conducted at 180 °C for 24 h in an electric oven. The system was then cooled to ambient temperature naturally. BiT nanorods were collected and washed with distilled water and absolute alcohol several times, vacuum-dried, and kept for further characterization. Bulk bismuth titanate powder used Bi 2 O 3 (Aldrich, 99.99) and TiO 2 (Aldrich, 99.99) as starting materials in the right stoichiometric ratio and then calcined at 600 °C for 2 h was also prepared by a traditional solid-state reaction in comparison with the BiT nanorods.

The samples in this work were prepared by the HTG method and conventional solid-state reaction method. For HTG synthesis, starting materials were Ca(NO 3 ) 2 4H 2 O (high grade, Kanto Kagaku, Japan), Ce(NO 3 ) 3 6H 2 O, Sc 2 O 3 (99.99%, Nippon Yttrium Co., Ltd., Japan), tetraethoxysilane (TEOS) (95%, Kanto Kagaku, Japan), nitric acid (61%, Kanto Kagaku, Japan). Ca(NO 3 ) 2 and Ce(NO 3 ) 3 were dissolved in distilled water, and Sc 2 O 3 was dissolved in nitric acid. All solutions were mixed together with TEOS in a volume ratio which corresponded to a molar ratio of Ca:Ce:Sc:Si = 2.97:0.03:2.00:3:00. The solution was put into an autoclave, which was then sealed, placed in an oven (ANS-111S, Isuzu, Japan) and heated to 200 C for 24 h. After this hydrothermal treatment, the resulting gel had been transferred from the vessel into a cone ﬂask, which was then covered with a lid. This ﬂask was kept in a dry oven at 120 C until all the water had evaporated, and was then placed in a mantle heater (MS-20, Omtop, Japan) and heated to 500 C to remove organic residues. This process was used to obtain the precursor, which was later subjected to heat-treatment in order to form the phosphor material. A reference sample was prepared by SSR synthesis. Starting materials were CaCO 3 (high grade, Kanto Kagaku, Japan), Ce(CH 3 COO) 3 (Kanto Kagaku, Japan), Sc 2 O 3 (99.99%, Nippon Yttrium Co., Ltd., Japan), and SiO 2 (70 nm, Wako, Japan). The reagents were mixed in an agate mortar in the same molar ratio as for the HTG method to form a powder mixture (SSR precursor).

The synthesis of Mg 2 Si is challenging for a number of reasons, namely the high afﬁnity of magnesium for oxygen, the high vapor pressure of Mg, the high melting temperature of silicon at 1687 K, and the almost identical melting point of Mg 2 Si at 1358 K and boiling point of Mg at 1363 K.
As a consequence, many Mg 2 Si samples exhibit MgO impurities.
40 Therefore, several different methods in addition to classical ceramic methods have been devised, including the vertical Bridgman method using molten Mg 2 Si, 41 crystal growth from molten Mg 2 Si 1x Ge x , 42 B 2 O 3 ﬂux method, 43 microwave assisted fast synthesis after ball-milling, 44 vacuum plasma spray, 45 a solid-state metathesis reaction of NaSi, MgCl 2 and Na, 46 and liquid encapsulated vertical gradient freezing using a KCl/MgCl 2 eutectic mixture as encapsulant.
47 Recently, an ‘‘ultrafast self-propagating high-temperature synthesis’’ was developed in which a cylinder of Mg, Si and Sb reacted after ignition within seconds in air to yield Sb-doped Mg 2 Si.
48 The same authors also prepared other thermoelectrics via this method.
49 In several of these methods, an excess of magnesium was used to compensate for its vapor loss.

KCa 2 Nb 3 O 10 was also prepared by a solid-state reaction method according to a previous report.
18 K 2 CO 3 (Z99.5%, Kanto Chemical Co.), CaCO 3 (Z99.5%, Kanto Chemical Co.), and Nb 2 O 5 (Z99.95%, Kanto Chemical Co.) were mixed with an agate mortar and pestle at a molar ratio of K/Ca/Nb = 1.1/2/3, and the mixture was calcined in air at 1123 K for 1 h. An excess of K 2 CO 3 (10 mol% excess K) was added to compensate for loss due to volatilization. After cooling to room temperature, the sample was mixed again, and was calcined in air at 1423 K for 10 h. The as-prepared material was subject to proton-exchange in the same manner.

Sr 2x Na x MgSi 2 O 70.5x powder samples with nominal composition x ¼ 0, 0.1, 0.2, 0.3, and 0.4 were prepared by sol–gel synthesis. Stoichiometric amounts of the proper nitrate and tetraethoxysilane (TEOS) were mixed in a 25 vol% water : 75 vol% ethanol solution. The solution was vigorously stirred for 48 hours and then kept at 85  C until complete evaporation of the solvent. Calcination at 1000  C was performed to remove organic components, followed by a thermal treatment at temperatures ranging from 1400  C to 800  C depending on composition. Some samples were prepared by solid-state synthesis also, starting from proper amounts of Na 2 CO 3 , SrCO 3 , MgO and SiO 2 .

Three kinds of samples are studied in this paper. They are BaSb 2 O 6 synthesized by solid state reaction (SSR-BaSb 2 O 6 ), rose-flower-like BaSb 2 O 6 (R-BaSb 2 O 6 ), marigold-flower-like BaSb 2 O 6 (M-BaSb 2 O 6 ). In the synthesis of SSR-BaSb 2 O 6 ,a molar ratio mixture of Sb 2 O 3 and Ba(NO 3 ) 2 were calcined in air at 600 uC for 12 hours. After grinding, the white powders were reacted at 1050 uC for 24 hours. Flower-like BaSb 2 O 6 (the general name for R-BaSb 2 O 6 and M-BaSb 2 O 6 ) was synthesized by a facile hydrothermal method. In a typical procedure, a certain amount of Ba(CH 3 COO) 2 ?2H 2 O was dissolved in 10 mL of deionized water followed by adding 25 mL of 0.1 mol L 21 KSb(OH) 6 solution drop by drop, and then the pH value and the volume of the mixture were adjusted to an appropriate value.
After being stirred at room temperature for 12 hours, the suspension was transferred into a Teflon-lined stainless autoclave, heated at 200 uC for several hours, and was finally cooled to room temperature. The white precipitation was obtained at the bottom of autoclave, and was collected by centrifugation (4500 rpm for 3 min). The collected precipitation was washed alternately with deionized water and ethanol, and dried in 60 uC oven.

The layered Li-excess nickel-manganese oxide (LL2NMO) was synthesized from mixed nickel-manganese carbonate precursors (Ni 0.25 Mn 0.75 CO 3 ) obtained via a co-precipitation method. A 0.2 M mixed NiSO 4 and MnSO 4 aqueous solution (Ni : Mn ¼ 1 : 3) was added drop-wise to an equal volume of a 1 M NaHCO 3 aqueous solution under constant stirring of 250 rpm at 50  C.
The pH was maintained at 8 by adding ammonium hydroxide.
The mixed solution containing green precipitates that are formed immediately, was aged for 24 h under the same conditions of the co-precipitation procedure. The Ni 0.25 Mn 0.75 CO 3 precipitate was ﬁltered, washed with deionized water several times, and dried overnight at 120  C. The dried powder was mixed with a 5% excess of stoichiometric amount of Li 2 CO 3 to compensate for possible lithium loss during the calcination. The mixture was heated at 1000  C for 6 h in air then quenched to room temperature using two copper plates. The spinel lithium manganese oxide (LiMn 2 O 4 ) was synthesized by the solid-state method. The mixture of LiOH and MnO 2 (Li:Mn¼ 1 : 2) was heated in air ﬁrst at 750  C for 4 h, then ground, and eventually they were reheated again for 12 h at 750  C.

The critical parameter that controls the stoichiometry of Li 12x Ni 11x O 2 is oxygen diffusion. Taking into account the above consideration, a successful synthesis of pure and Ga-substituted LiNiO 2 has to be expected only under high oxygen pressure, stabilizing Ni 31 ions. The LiGa y Ni 12y O 2 solid solutions were prepared by solid state reaction between Ga 2 O 3 (b-form, Aldrich), NiO (obtained from thermal decomposition of nickel hydroxide at 550 uC) and Li 2 O 2 (Aldrich) at 700 uC, with pressures between 3 and 4 GPa for 2.5 hours. The Li/(Ni 1 Ga) ratio in the mixture was 1.2. For the sake of comparison, ternary LiGa 0.1 (Ni 12x Co x ) 0.9 O 2 compositions were prepared from a ‘‘Ga 2 O 3 –NiO–Co 3 O 4 – Li 2 O 2 ’’ mixture at 3 GPa and 750 uC(x ~ 0.8) and 800 uC (x ~ 0.2), respectively.

Stoichiometric molar quantities of SnO (Sigma Aldrich, 99.99%) and Nb 2 O 5 (Aldrich, 99.99%) were mixed homogenously by grinding for 20 min under an argon atmosphere. SnCl 2 (Aldrich, 99.99%) was added as a flux to provide diﬀerent reactant to flux molar ratios (1 : 1-F, 1 : 3-F, 1 : 6-F, 1 : 10-F, and 1 : 14-F, F stands for flux). The mixture was ground again for 10 min under an argon atmosphere. The obtained mixture was transferred into an alumina boat and heated inside a tubular furnace under the nitrogen flow at a flow rate of 100 ml min 1 . Diﬀerent reaction temperatures (300, 500, and 600 1C) were tested for 10 h, followed by radiative cooling to room temperature. The obtained samples were then washed by stirring overnight in Milli-Q water (18.2 MO cm 1 ) to remove the remaining SnCl 2 flux. The obtained powders were dried at 70 1C. Solid-state synthesis was performed by grinding for 30 min and heating for 10 h at 800 1C, as reported previously.

All of the reagents were analytical grade and used without further puriﬁcations.
Nanocrystalline pyrochlore AgSbO 3 samples were prepared by a hydrothermal method.
In a typical procedure, Sb 2 O 5 powder (0.24 g, 0.75 mmol) was added to 70 ml aqueous solution containing AgAc (0.25 g, 1.5 mmol) under vigorous stirring.
The pH of the resulting mixture was adjusted by nitric acid solution or sodium hydrate solution.
The mixture was loaded into a 100 mL Teﬂon-lined autoclave and sealed tightly.
The autoclaves were kept at 180 ◦ C for 48 h.
After cooling to room temperature, the precipitate was collected, washed with distilled water and absolute ethanol for several times, and then dried in air at 80 ◦ C.
For comparison, bulk pyrochlore AgSbO 3 sample was prepared from Ag 2 O and Sb 2 O 5 via the conventional solid-state reaction according to the literature.

The experiments of crystal growth were carried out in a vertical cylindrical electric furnace. The furnace temperature was measured by a Pt-Rh thermocouple and controlled by an FP-21 digital microprocessor temperature programmer-controller. The procedure of crystal growth was as follows: polycrystalline Ga 3 PO 7 was ﬁrst synthesized using a standard solid-state reaction method from 4N pure reagent grade Ga 2 O 3 and analytically pure reagent grade NH 4 H 2 PO 4 , and poured into the liquid mixture of the Li 2 O–3MoO 3 system at 1173 K in a platinum crucible in a vertical furnace. The synthesis of LiMn 2 O 4 nanorods is carried out through a twostep procedure. Firstly, the tetragonal β-MnO 2 nanorods were prepared by a hydrothermal process similar to the previous report [15].
Typically, 10 mmol MnSO 4 and 10 mmol (NH 4 ) 2 S 2 O 8 were dissolved in 140 ml of distilled water to form a homogeneous solution under magnetically stirring at room temperature. The mixed solution was transferred to a 200 ml Teﬂon-lined stainless autoclave and heated at 120 °C for 12 h. The resultant precipitate was washed with deionized water and ethanol in succession to remove the sulfate ions and other remnants. The obtained black powder was subsequently dried at 80 °C for 24 h in air to obtain the β-MnO 2 precursor. Secondly, the above β-MnO 2 and LiOH·H 2 O were mixed at 2:1 molar ratio and dispersed into 5 ml methanol to form a thick slurry, which was further ground for several hours, and then dried at room temperature.
The obtained powder was calcined in tube furnace at 700 °C for 10 h in air to obtain spinel LiMn 2 O 4 nanorods (marked as LiMn 2 O 4 -NRS).
As a contrast, LiMn 2 O 4 particles were also prepared by a traditional solid state reaction method (marked as LiMn 2 O 4 -SSR) from commercially available β-MnO 2 without any further treatment and LiOH·H 2 O mixed at the same molar ratio of 2:1. For all calcinations in tube furnace, samples were heated from room temperature at a heating rate of 10 °C min − 1 and cooled naturally to room temperature. Tin doping Introduction Lithium-ion batteries have been studied for the past several decades due to their high energy density and capacity. The cycle life and capacity of the lithium-ion cells critically depend on the structural and electrochemical properties of the cathode materials. Currently, the research on the cathode for lithium-ion batteries has been focused on three materials (LiCoO 2 ,LiNiO 2 and LiMn 2 O 4 )andtheir derivatives [1–6]. Generally, LiCoO 2 is used as commercial cathode materials due to its high reversibility, reasonable rate capacity and easy preparation, but it suffers from high cost and the relatively high toxicity of cobalt. LiNiO 2 is a more attractive material than LiCoO 2 because of its low cost and possibility of higher rechargeable capacity [7].
Nevertheless, stoichiometric LiNiO 2 is difficult to be obtained because of the loss of lithium from the host structure due to the high vapor pressure of lithium at high sintering temperature. Therefore, much research has been undertaken to search for new cathode materials to overcome these shortcomings.
In recent years, the lithium nickel cobalt mixed oxides have played an important role in the field of lithium-ion batteries [8, 9]. The solid solution, LiNi 1-y Co y O 2 (0<y<1) is being closely scrutinized as a possible substitute for LiCoO 2 because it has both advantages of LiNiO 2 and LiCoO 2 , which is based on the fact that LiNiO 2 and LiCoO 2 have the same layered α-NaFeO 2 -type structure [10, 11]. Among them, LiNi 0.90 Co 0.10 O 2 appears to be much more promising.
Elements such as Fe, Al, Mn, and Y have been used for partial substitution of Ni or Co to further enhance the electrochemical performance of the cathode materials [12–14]. The doped materials show better structural stability and cycling behavior than undoped ones.
In this study, for the first time, tin-doped LiNi 0.9 Co 0.1 O 2 cathode material is synthesized by the rheological phase reaction method, which does not need troublesome processes such as pelletizing, washing, stirring, and repeated heat treatment [15]. The effects of tin doping on the structure and electrochemical properties are discussed in detail.

1 Introduction The idea of using a solid state dielectric material as a resonator in wireless telecommunication devices, satellite broadcasting equipment and mobiles handsets, was ﬁrst ﬂoated by Richtmyer in 1939 [1]. The suitability of a material to be used in microwave dielectric resonators depends on three important characteristics. A high dielectric constant (e r ) is required for miniaturization of the component, a high quality factor (Q 9 f) is needed for ﬁne tunability and near zero temperature coefﬁcient of resonant frequency (s f ) for temperature stability [2]. In general, materials don’t exhibit all these properties simultaneously; however, a number of materials have the ability to host different cations to form new compounds to enhance the desired properties and suppress the unwanted ones [1].
Perovskite structured materials like CaTiO 3 ,BaTiO 3 and SrTiO 3 have been studied for their potential applications as dielectric resonators. Among these, CaTiO 3 is a natural perovskite mineral discoveredbyGustavRosein1839[3]and was named perovskite after the name of well-known mineralogist Perovskii [4, 5]. CaTiO 3 has an orthorhombic (Pbnm) structure at room temperature [6] and has been reported to exhibit reasonable e r (*160) and Q 9 f (*7,000 GHz); however, its s f (*850 ppm/°C) is too high for microwave dielectric applications [7]. In order to tailor its microwave dielectric properties via structural variations, it can be doped with a number of cations. Doping trivalent cations (like La 3? , Nd 3? ,Sm 3? ,Y 3? ,Pr 3? ) on the A-site of the CaTiO 3 unit cell creates a number of vacancies to neutralize charge [3]. The creation of these vacancies leads to doubling of the unit cell which results in structural distortion [8]. Superconducting samples of type   SmBa 2 Cu 3−x Ru x O 7−δ  were prepared by a solid-state reaction technique. Coherence length along c-axis  𝜉 c ( 0 )  , eﬀective layer thickness of superconducting layers  d  ,   the thermodynamic critical magnetic ﬁeld  B c (0)  , penetration depth  𝜆(0)  , lower critical magnetic ﬁeld  B c1  , upper critical magnetic ﬁeld  B c2  , critical current density  J c (0)  , Fermi  velocity  v F  , phase relaxation time of Cooper pair  𝜏 𝜑  , coupling constant  P   and energy required to break apart Cooper  pair  E pb   were calculated as a function of Ru-content. Magneto-conductivity is another tool to study the superconducting order parameters ﬂuctuations. In the magnetoconductivity measurements, the normal state resistivity  is canceled and its temperature dependence is no longer  needed. As the magneto-conductivity involves the nonzero  magnetic ﬁelds, it is considered as a more subtle probing  of the transport properties in the ﬂuctuation region than the  excess conductivity [18]. The magneto-conductivity data is  also analyzed taking into account the orbital contribution  according to AL and MT models for layered superconductors [14, 19]. Moreover, some important physical quantities  of intrinsic superconducting can be determined from the  magneto-conductivity ﬂuctuation analysis above T c .
In this work, the measured data of electrical resistivity versus temperature for the superconducting samples of  type   SmBa 2 Cu 3−x Ru x O 7−δ  with x = 0.00–0.30 was analyzed  through excess conductivity and magneto-conductivity  in absence and presence of applied dc magnetic ﬁeld of  0.44 T, respectively. Many superconducting parameters  were calculated from the analysis of both excess conductivity and magneto-conductivity as a function of Ru-content  for Sm-123 phase.
2   Experimental  details Superconducting samples of type  SmBa 2 Cu 3−x Ru x O 7−δ ,  with x = 0.00, 0.05, 0.10, 0.20 and 0.30 were prepared using  conventional solid-state reaction technique. High purity  powders (99.99%, Aldrich Chem. Co.) of  Sm 2 O 3 ,   BaO 2 ,  CuO and  RuO 2 , with stoichiometric ratios 1:2:3−x:x, were  mixed, thoroughly grounded in an agate mortar and sifted  by 125μm sieve to get homogeneous mixture. The powder  was subjected to calcination process to remove any remaining volatile materials. This process was done twice in air  at 840 and 880 °C for 24h each with intermediate grinding and sieving. The obtained powder was again ground,  sifted and ﬁnally pressed into pellets using a hydraulic  press under 15 ton/cm 2  pressure to decrease the number of  voids and minimize the intergrain contact problems. Magnesium bismuth vanadium oxide (MBV) sample was  prepared by solid-state reaction technique. The TNO nanospheres were prepared via a simple solvothermal method combined with heat treatment. 0.60 g P123 (EO 20 PO 70 EO 20 , Aladdin, 99.5%) was dissolved in 60 mL of ethanol with vigorous stirring for 15 min. Then, 0.568 g titanium isopropoxide (C 12 H 28 O 4 Ti, TIP; 97%, Aladdin) and 2.7 g niobium chloride (NbCl 5 ; 99.99%, Aladdin) were added according to stoichiometric proportion with stirring for an additional 30 min. For comparison, the TNO microrods were synthesized by a facile solid–state reaction method using Nb 2 O 5 (Aldrich, 99.9%) and TiO 2 (Aldrich, 99%) powders as raw materials according to the stoichiometric proportion of Ti : Nb ¼ 1 : 5, which were mixed and ball-milled for 1.5 h by using a high-energy ball milling machine (SPEX 8000 M, USA) and calcined in a high-temperature tube furnace at 1200  C for 5 h in air.

HTiNbO 5 was prepared in two steps: (i) solid state reaction synthesis of KTiNbO 5 , 22 (ii) ion exchange reaction of H + for K + in KTiNbO 5 .
21 Thus, stoichiometric amounts of K 2 CO 3 ,Nb 2 O 5 and TiO 2 were intimately mixed, preheated at 650  C and then heated at 1200  C for 12 h in a platinum crucible in air. The Na 2/3 Li 0.18 Mn 0.8 Fe 0.2 O 2 pristine compound was obtained via a simple solid-state reaction. Stoichiometric amounts of Na 2 CO 3 (Sigma Aldrich, anhydrous), Li 2 CO 3 (Sigma Aldrich, purity: 99%), Mn 2 O 3 (Alfa Aesar, purity: 98%) and Fe 2 O 3 (Alfa Aesar, purity: 99%) were manually mixed with a mortar and pestle. A 5% wt. excess of Li 2 CO 3 was added to the mixture to compensate lithium loss upon heating. Planetary ball milling (Pulverisette7, Fritsch) was used to ensure a good level of homogeneity, aer which the product was pressed into a pellet.
The pellet was subsequently calcined under air at 3  C min 1 to 1000  C for 6 hours, then slowly cooled to 250  C. The sample was then rapidly transferred to an argon-lled glove box at <0.1 ppm O 2 and <0.1 ppm H 2 O, where it was stored until usage.

LiMnPO 4 used in this study was synthesized by RAPET method. In a typical procedure, stoichiometric amounts of NH 4 H 2 PO 4 ,Li 2 CO 3 , and MnO 2 are mixed. The mixture was ground, pressed into a pellet, and taken in a Swagelok.
It was then fired at 700 °C for 10 h in a tubular furnace.
The rate of heating and cooling was maintained at 10 °C / min. LiTi 2 (PO 4 ) 3 was also synthesized by the same method and was used as anode material. The synthesized samples were characterized by X-ray powder diffraction (XRD) using Philips X’pert Pro Diffractometer (Cu K radiation, secondary graphite monochromator). All of the reagents used were from Sigma–Aldrich and used as received.

Anorthite (CaO–2SiO 2 –Al 2 O 3 ) was prepared by ultrasonic mixing of 34 g of Al 2 O 3 powder (Sumitomo AKP 50) with 30.03 g of CaCO 3 and 36.05 g SiO 2 in 25 g H 2 O. The paste was dried and then heat treated in air at a temperature of 1600 C for 4 h to obtain anorthite glass. After equilibration, the anorthite glass was ground to a ﬁne powder, mixed into a slurry using ethanol and dispersed on the surface of the sapphire substrates. After drying, the coated sapphire substrates were heat treated at 1600 C for 1 h to form micron-sized droplets of glass on the (0001) sapphire surfaces. Another set of samples was prepared using the same procedure, but bulk pieces of anorthite glass were partially wetted on the annealed sapphire substrate. In the following, identical results were obtained regardless of the method used to wet the sapphire substrates with anorthite.

BBN powders were prepared using BaCO 3 ,Bi 2 O 3 , and Nb 2 O 5 as starting materials (All from Kojundo Chemical Lab.). Stoichiometric amounts of the starting materials were simultaneously ball-milled with distilled water for 24 h.
The mixed slurry was dried and heated at 600–1,000 C for 4 h under an oxygen flow.

BaMgF 4 was synthesized by mechanical treatment of the binary fluorides in a high-energy ball mill (Fritsch Pulverisette 7 premium line). Stoichiometric amounts of BaF 2 and MgF 2 were milled using 180 balls made of zirconium dioxide (ZrO 2 ) with a diameter of 5 mm in beakers of the same material. Pr 2 ZnZrO 6 polycrystalline sample was synthesized by conventional solid state reaction method using high purity Pr 2 O 3 , ZnO and ZrO 2 and stoichiometrically mixed in a agate mortar in the presence of acetone (Merck) for 12 h.
The mixture was calcined in a Pt crucible at 1,100 °C in air for 10 h and brought to room temperature at a cooling rate of 100 °C/h. The calcined sample was palletized into a circular disc using PVA as binder which was burnt out during sintering at 1,150 °C for 6 h, and cooled slowly to room temperature at a cooling rate 1 °C/min. NTC thermistor powders with a chemical composition of Mn 1-x Sr x CoNiO 4 (0 B9B0.2) were prepared by solid state reactions at room temperature. Polycrystalline specimen of Ca 3 Co 2 O 6 was prepared by solid state reaction method as described earlier [Ref. 21] starting from stoichiometric amounts of respective high purity (.99.99%) oxides, CaCO 3 , and Co 3 O 4 . Pure and 1.5 at% Y-doped BST thin ﬁlms were deposited by Pulsed laser deposition (PLD) technique. A KrF excimer laser radiation (k = 248 nm, 650 mJ, 25 ns) was focused on a rotating target set in the chamber though a quartz window. Note that the Ba 0.6 Sr 0.4 TiO 3 and Y-doped BST ceramics were made by conventional solid-state reaction in air using BaCO 3 (99.9% purity), SrCO 3 (99.9% purity), TiO 2 (99.9% purity), Y 2 O 3 (99.999% purity) as starting materials. The incident angel of laser beam to the target surface was ﬁxed to be 45. Substrate were placed parallel to the target surface with a target-substrate distance of 50 mm. Pure oxygen was used as reactive agent during deposition, and was introduced into the chamber through a needle valve. The substrate was heated by radiation from Pt resistive heater with a thermocouple embedded in the heater. The BST and Y-BST targets were fabricated using conventional solid-state reaction. About 300 nm pure and Y-doped BST thin ﬁlms were grown on the (100) LaAlO 3 single crystal substrates, respectively. The substrate temperature and the oxygen ambient pressure during the growth of both ﬁlms were 650 C and 25 Pa, respectively.
To reduce oxygen deﬁciency, the samples were in situ annealed in 0.5 atm oxygen at 700 C for 1 h, and then cooled down slowly to room temperature. Ca 3 Co 4 O 9 ceramics were synthesized by the PC method and HHP technique as summarized in Fig. 1. Citric acid and stoichiometric amounts of calcium acetate hydrate and cobalt acetate hydrate were dissolved in ethylene glycol by heating and stirring the solution until complete dissolution.
At ﬁrst, the solution was heated at 433 K to remove most of the water from the solution. After the completion of the decomposition of acetate ions, the temperature of the solution was gradually increased to 523 K. During this heating process, the formation of the polymer between ethylene glycol and metal-citrate complexes was promoted.
As the solution was condensed, it became viscous, and this viscous product was decomposed to a ﬁne powder at 723 K. The obtained powder precursor was ground and calcined at 973 K for 12 h in air to remove a residual organic matter completely. The calcined powder was compressed by the hydrothermal hot-pressing technique similar to that reported in our previous studies [15, 16]. The calcined powder was kneaded with 0.05 M NaOH solution (10 mass% for the powder) to be set in the cylinder of an autoclave for the hydrothermal hot pressing (HHP).
Figure 2 shows the schematic drawing of the autoclave used in this experiment. The autoclave has a cylinder made of stainless steel with an inside diameter of 20 mm and the sample is compressed by the piston in the cylinder from the top and bottom. The sample was ﬁrst compressed at the ambient temperature and the desired pressure (50– 200 MPa). Then it was heated at a rate of 10 K min -1 to the desired temperature (373–573 K), and kept for a desired time (1–5 h) at each temperature. The rectangular prism with about 18 9 7 9 2 mm was cut off from the obtained compacts. The cut off compacts were sintered at 1193 K for 12 h in air. As a reference, the sample by the conventional solid-state reaction method was also prepared; a mixture of CaCO 3 and Co 3 O 4 powders was pressed into a pellet under a pressure of 560 MPa for 30 s at room temperature, calcined at 1,173 K for 12 h in air, ground, again pressed into a pellet, and then sintered at 1,193 K for 12 h in air.

O3-LiCoO 2 was synthesized via solid-state reactions. Li 2 CO 3 (99.99%, Kojundo Chemical Laboratory) and Co 3 O 4 (99.9%, Rare Metallic) were used as the starting materials. The required amounts of starting materials were mixed and calcined at 650  C for 12 h in air. The product was then reground, pressed into pellets and sintered at 900  C for 24 h in an Al 2 O 3 tube in air.
O2-LiCoO 2 was synthesized by an ion-exchange reaction from P2-Na 0.70 CoO 2 precursor. To prepare the precursor, a mixture of Na 2 CO 3 (99.9%, Rare Metallic) and Co 3 O 4 was calcined at 650  C for 12 h in air, after which the reground product was pressed into pellets and sintered at 800  C for 12 h in an Al 2 O 3 tube under O 2 ﬂow. The prepared P2-Na 0.70 CoO 2 was then placed into a LiBr solution in ethanol (2 M) and exchanged at 95  C for 3 days. Following the exchange, the obtained powder was washed in ethanol, ﬁltered, and dried at 130  C under vacuum.
Synchrotron XAFS and XRD analyses of the pristine and de-intercalated lithium cobalt oxide samples were then carried out to investigate the lithium-ion de-intercalation processes. The electrode was made from suspensions containing 80 wt% active material, 10 wt% acetylene black, and 10 wt% polyvinylidene diﬂuoride, which were cast and pressed on an aluminum foil. The electrodes were assembled in a two-electrode cell using metallic lithium foil as a counter/reference electrode. A 1 mol dm 3 ethylene carbonate/dimethyl carbonate solution of LiPF 6 was used as the liquid electrolyte. Electrochemical de-intercalation of the lithium ion was carried out at a constant current rate of 1/40 C (about 0.042 mA cm 2 ).

Na 2 Ti 3 O 7 was synthesized by modification of our previously published pr otocol of the synthesis of nanocrystaline Li 4 Ti 5 O 12 [19]. Briefly, 1 M solution of sodium ethoxide (NaOEt, Aldrich) in absolute ethanol was mixed with a stoichiometric amount (4/5) of titanium (IV) isopropoxide (Ti(OPr) 4 , Aldrich). The solution was hydrolyzed with 2.7% aqueous solution of polyethylene glycol (molecular weight 20,000, Merck), stirred overnight and concentrated on rotary evaporator (40 °C, 20 mbar). The resulting slurry was then calcined at 500 °C 1 h (sample Na 2 Ti 3 O 7 _500) or at 600 °C 1h(sampleNa 2 Ti 3 O 7 _600). The reference sample Na 2 Ti 3 O 7 _1000 was prepared by a solid-state synthesis from the stoichiometric mixture of nanocrystalline TiO 2 (made by hydrolysis of titanium (IV) isopropoxide) and Na 2 CO 3 and calcined at 1000 °C for 20 h.

The synthesis of Zn 2 SiO 4 :Mn 2+ powder was performed with the HP method using the procedure described below. Aqueous solutions of Zn(NO 3 ) 2 (Kanto Chemical, 99.0%), Mn(NO 3 ) 2 (Wako Chemical, 98.0%), and PGMS were prepared, and urea (Kanto Chemical, 99.0%) or hexamethylene tetramine (HMT, Kanto Chemical, 99.0%) was used as a precipitant. The starting aqueous solutions were dispensed into a 300 mL beaker to achieve a stoichiometric ratio of Zn 1.96 Mn 0.04 SiO 4 , followed by addition of urea or HMT, and the mixture was stirred. As needed, before adding the precipitant, HCl was added to the mixed solution to set the initial pH to 2.5. Distilled water was added to the mixed solution to adjust the total concentration of metal and silicon to 0.1 M (75 mL). The beaker was covered and heated in a water bath to bring the solution temperature to 363 K, and was held for 4 to 24 h and stirred at 400 rpm by a magnetic stirrer equipped with a heating plate to obtain a precipitate. The precipitate was separated by ﬁltration, washed with distilled water, and dried to obtain a precursor. This precursor was annealed at various temperatures for 2 h to obtain a ﬁnal sample. A similar approach was performed using bulk SiO 2 (particle size: 63–270 mm, Kanto Chemical, 99.9%), fumed silica (particle size: 7 nm, Aldrich), or TEOS as the silicon source, and these were compared to samples prepared from PGMS. The samples obtained using PGMS, SiO 2 , fumed silica, and TEOS as silicon sources are hereafter referred to as HP-PGMS, HP-SiO 2 , HP-fs, and HP-TEOS, respectively. The synthesis of the sample by a solid-state reaction (SSR) using ZnO (Kanto Chemical, 99.0%), Mn 3 O 4 (Kojundo Chemical, 99.9%), and SiO 2 powder as starting materials was also performed. Raw materials were weighed in a stoichiometric ratio, then they were thoroughly mixed using ethanol in an agate mortar. The mixture was calcined at 973–1573 K for 2 hours in air. All samples in the present research were heat-treated without addition of any ﬂuxes. The resulting samples were characterized by a powder X-ray diffractometer (XRD; Bruker, D2 PHASER), a scanning electron microscope (SEM; Hitachi, S-4800) equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectra analyzer (EDS), and an inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscope (ICP-AES; Perkin Elmer, Optima 3300XL). For ICP-AES analysis, samples were dissolved into 10% HF solution, then it was diluted to obtain the proper concentration. Photoluminescence (PL) spectra of samples were obtained using a ﬂuorescence spectrometer (Hitachi, F4500). In the PL measurement, the pure sample without dilution was densely stuffed in a hole of a sample holder equipped with a quartz window. The sample holder ﬁlled with the sample was ﬁxed at the same position in a measurement room of the ﬂuorescence spectrometer using a jig for each measurement. Diffusion Introduction Lithium ion batteries are considered to be the best available power source for most portable electronic devices, owing to their higher energy density, larger power capacity, and higher working voltage, compared with other secondary batteries [1]. The cycle life and capacity of lithium ion batteries critically depend on the structural and electrochemical properties of the cathode materials. Traditionally, LiCoO 2 is used as commercial cathode material for lithium rechargeable batteries because of its high reversibility, reasonable rate capacity, and easy preparation. However, the toxicity of cobalt coupled with its high cost and low practical capacity limit further applications. Currently, LiNiO 2 is being developed to replace LiCoO 2 , due to the comparatively low cost, high energy density, and environmental advantages of the former. Nevertheless, this material is known to be difficult to synthesize and suffers from instabilities at high states of charge [2, 3]. Therefore, much research has been undertaken to search for new cathode materials to overcome these shortcomings [4–6].
LiNi 1−x Co x O 2 (0<x<1) compounds, which are isostructural as LiCoO 2 and LiNiO 2 with hexagonal R-3m αNaFeO 2 -layered structures and have the advantages of both LiCoO 2 and LiNiO 2 , are considered as promising cathode materials for lithium secondary batteries [7–10]. Elements such as Fe, Al, Y, and Ga have been used for the partial substitution of Ni or Co to further enhance the electrochemical performance of the cathode materials [11–14].
The doped materials showed better structural stability and cycling behavior than the undoped ones. However, the electrochemically inactive dopant generally reduced the reversible cycling capacity.
In the present study, we report an improved reversible capacity and cycling performance of Ca-doped LiNi 0.8 Co 0.2 O 2 cathode material. The structural and electrochemical properties were investigated to find the reasons for the improvement in electrochemical properties.

Layered lithium trivanadate (LiV 3 O 8 ) was prepared via solidstate reaction. The starting material LiV 3 O 8 was prepared via a solid-state reaction of lithium hydroxide monohydrate (LiOH.H 2 O, E-merck) and vanadium pentoxide (V 2 O 5 ,Emerck). Stoichiometric LiOH.H 2 OandV 2 O 5 (atomic molar ratio Li/V=1:5) were mixed and finely ground in an agate mortar. The mixture was then heated at 500 °C in air for 16 h as previously described [27]. 0.5 gm of PMMA (M w = 15,000, Aldrich) was completely dissolved in 50 ml of acetone and 2 g of LiV 3 O 8 was dissolved in 80 ml of ethanol. Both the solutions were mixed, stirred at 60 °C for 3 h, and then the mixed slurry was sealed in a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave at 100 °C for 1 d. All the chemicals in this work were used as obtained: silver powder, 99.9% purity, Aldrich; lead, 99.9% purity, Merck; antimony powder, 99.995% purity, Aldrich; bismuth powder, 99.9% purity, Merck; Sb 2 S 3 powder, 99.9% purity, Merck; sulfur powder, 99.98% purity, Sigma-Aldrich. The solid solutions type AgPbSb 1− x Bi x S 3 (x=0, 0.2, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7, 0.8, and 1.0) were prepared by solid state reaction in evacuat ed quartz ampoules and could be obtained by two ways as follows: (a) Ag, Pb, Sb 2 S 3 , Bi, and S wer e mixed in stoichiometric proportions.
The reaction mixture was gradually heated to 600 °C over 12 h, kept at that temperature for 5 days, and slowly cooled to 50 °C at 12 °C/h. (b) Ag, Pb, Sb, Bi, and S were mixed in stoichiometric proportions. The reaction mixture was gradually heated to 800 °C over 18 h, kept at that temperature for 3 days, and slowly cooled to 50 °C at 12 °C/h. The reaction products are the same from either of the temperature processes. The chemical composition of the samples was determined by SEM-EDX analysis using a JEOL 5400 system equipped with an Oxford LinK ISIS microanalyz er. The XRD data were collected at room temperature using a Siemens D5000 powder diffractometer, with CuK α radiation in the 5° to 80° (2θ) range. The lattice parameters were calculated using a CHECKCELL program [9]. Differential thermal analysis (DTA) and thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) were performed on a Rheometric Scientific STA 1500H/625 Thermal Analysis System. The DTA/TGA curves were run simultaneously on each sample from room temperature to 1000 °C, in flowing nitrogen at a heating rate of 10 °C/min. The electrica l properties were studied by ac impedance spectroscopy and dc methods. The experiments were conducted in the temperature range of 12 to 350 °C in argon atmosphere. The pellets for electrical measurements were uniaxially pressed at ∼5×10 8 Pa, resulting in cylindrical pellets of 7 mm in diameter and thickness of 1 to 3 mm, corresponding to an average density ∼2.8 gcm −3 . The dc current–voltage and current–temperature were measured using a Keithley model 237 source electrometer.
The current–voltage curves were verified to be linear, supporting the ohmic character of the contacts. The ac impedance–fr equency measurement was carried out in argon atmosphere using a Solartron Instruments model 1260 analyzer. The frequency range was from 0.1 Hz to 10 MHz with a signal level between 25 mV and 1 V.

Secondly, solution 1 was added into solution 3 slowly under stirring followed by stirring for 20 min, then solution 2 was added into the preceding mixed solution under stirring, and the mixed solutions were then stirred for 1 h at room temperature after the pH value was adjusted to 3.
Then, the mixture was dried at 85 °C for 15 h and 125 °C for 8 h in a drying oven, followed by drying at 350 °C for 3 h in a mufﬂe furnace to form the precursor. Finally, different CCTO powders were obtained by calcining the precursor at 700, 750, 800, 850, 900 and 1000 °C for 10 h, respectively. The as-prepared different CCTO powders were pressed into different pellets with the diameter of 10 mm under the pressure of 200 MPa. Different CCTO ceramics were obtained by sintering the different pellets at 1050 °C for 20 h.

Sr 2 Nb 2 O 7 powders were obtained by reacting stoichiometric ratios of SrCO 3 (Alfa Aesar 99%, pure) and Nb 2 O 5 (Alfa Aesar, 99.5% pure) in air at 1,400 °C for 100 h.
Powder X-ray diffraction was used to conﬁrm the phase purity. BaTiO 3 powders were obtained from a commercial source (Alfa Aesar, 99.7% pure). Small, faceted BaTiO 3 and Sr 2 Nb 2 O 7 crystals were produced using a molten salt ﬂux method. Equal weights of the target phase and KCl (Fisher Scientiﬁc) were combined by wet grinding in ethanol for several minutes. The slurry was then transferred to a Pyrex beaker and mixed by magnetic stirring for 2 h.
Following mixing, the excess ethanol was decanted with a pipet and the powders were dried in air at 70 °C. The dried powder was transferred to an Al 2 O 3 crucible and heated in air at 5 °C/min to 1,100 °C for 6 h. The KCl was removed by ﬁltering with boiling deionized water and the remaining product was dried in air at 70 °C. The identity of the phase was conﬁrmed by powder X-ray diffraction.

BaFe 0.9 Zr 0.1 O 3d (BFZ) powder was made by conventional solid-state synthesis with proper amounts of BaCO 3 (Alfa Aesar, 99.997%), Fe 2 O 3 (Alfa Aesar, 99.99%), and ZrO 2 (Aldrich, 99.99%). The mixed powder was ball-milled overnight with zirconia media in isopropyl alcohol (IPA). After drying on a hot plate, the mixture was heated at 850  C for 10 h in ambient air and ball-milled again overnight. The dried powder was heated at 900  C for 10 h and ball-milled for 24 h, then the powder was pressed uniaxially into disks (z1-in. dia). Dense ceramic disks were prepared by sintering in air, in N 2 , and in 100 ppm H 2 /N 2 at 1330e1350  C for 6e10 h. To observe the effect of Zr 4þ doping on the oxygen permeation ﬂux, another composition, BaFe 0.975 Zr 0.025 O 3d (BFZ0), was made by sintering at 1250  C for 6 h in 100 ppm H 2 /N 2 . The crystal structure, microstructure, and purity were determined for the BFZ samples sintered in different environments. For the coal-gas-assisted watersplitting experiment, a BFZ tube with one end closed was prepared in the N 2 atmosphere (O.D. of 0.96 cm, I.D. of 0.75 cm, and length of 5.74 cm). The thickness of the tube was determined to be 1.05 mm, and the tube’s outside and inside surface area was 17.3 cm 2 and 13.5 cm 2 , respectively. To activate the surface of a 0.67-mm-thick BFZ disk during EtOH reforming, Rh catalyst was deposited on one of its faces. Rhodium nitrate, Rh(NO 3 ) 3 ,2H 2 O (Alfa Aesar, 99.9%), was dissolved in deionized water, and then XUS binder (poly-vinyl butyral) and BFZ powder were added to the solution. Heating the solution with binder and powder at <80  C while stirring gave a viscous paste, which was painted onto the surface of the BFZ disk. The painted disk was dried in air and installed for an ethanol reforming test at 600  C.
